channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: With Bakhmut in Ruins, Ukraine Shifts Focus to City’s Outskirts
item.description: Ukraine’s top military commander concedes that only a small contingent of troops is still defending Bakhmut, site of the war’s deadliest battle.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: What Bakhmut Looks Like Now
item.description: Drone footage taken by The New York Times captured the scorched buildings, destroyed schools and cratered parks that now define the city in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora

item.title: E.U. Asks Greece to Investigate Video of Migrants Left at Sea
item.description: Citing a report by The Times, a top E.U. official said the Greek authorities had been urged to investigate after footage showed the Greek Coast Guard leaving asylum seekers at sea.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A still from a video showing a Greek Coast Guard vessel and migrants. A Times investigation verified and corroborated the footage.

item.title: Mexican Official, Alejandro Encinas, Victim of Pegasus Spyware Attack
item.description: While looking into abuses by the armed forces, the country’s top human rights official was targeted with Pegasus, the world’s most notorious spyware, The Times found.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Alejandro Encinas, Mexico’s under secretary for human rights, was targeted by spyware while investigating abuses by the nation’s military.

item.title: Fire in Guyana School Dormitory Kills at Least 19
item.description: Many of the victims in the overnight blaze were children, and the government was flying out some of the injured so they could receive treatment.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Children rescued from a fire in the girls’ dormitory of a school in Mahdia, Guyana, being transferred by medical personnel on Monday at a hospital in Georgetown, the capital.

item.title: Why Bakhmut? It’s a Question Older Than the Ukraine War.
item.description: The twists and turns of a war are rarely easy to predict. In Ukraine, they landed on a city in the east that few had ever heard of. And then the whole world watched for months.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Much of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, already seemed shelled to oblivion in December.

item.title: Andrew Tate Finds Romania Less Lawless Than He Hoped
item.description: The online influencer, popular with young men, is facing charges of human trafficking and rape, after seeking out a place where “corruption is accessible to everybody.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, left, and his younger brother, Tristan, outside court in Bucharest in February. Mr. Tate has said he liked “living in a society where my money, my influence and my power” meant that he was not beholden to laws.

item.title: The Sound of France’s Pension Fury? The Saucepan.
item.description: Protesters have been harassing the French government in clanky demonstrations that have gone viral in a country with no shortage of kitchenware.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Protesters across France have taken to the streets with pots, pans, lids and spoons to make known their frustration over President Emmanuel Macron’s pension changes.

item.title: Fire Guts Manila’s Historic Post Office Building
item.description: Built in 1926, the structure is one of the Philippine capital’s most recognizable landmarks. The cause of the fire was unclear on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez

item.title: Greece Elections: New Democracy on Track to Win Most Votes
item.description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis’s New Democracy party did not win enough votes to form a one-party government. But he appeared to rule out talks to form a coalition, setting the stage for a second vote in weeks.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Supporters of the governing New Democracy party in Athens after the first exit polls came in on Sunday.

item.title: Sudan’s Warring Sides Agree to Weeklong Ceasefire
item.description: The truce is the first to be signed by both sides. It followed weeks of talks in Saudi Arabia between representatives of the two rival generals vying for power in the northeast African nation.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Saudi officials looked on as representatives of the Sudanese Army and the rival paramilitary Rapid Support Forces signed an agreement in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on Saturday for a cease-fire.

item.title: Biden Announces More Aid for Ukraine as G7 Powers Meet in Japan
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Hiroshima, Japan, on Sunday.

item.title: Fleeing Afghanistan, U.S. Allies Risk Journey Through Darién Gap
item.description: For thousands of Afghans, the American withdrawal from Kabul was just the beginning of a long, dangerous search for safety.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: 95-Year-Old Australian Woman Is Tasered by Police
item.description: She was holding a knife, but weighs 95 pounds and uses a walker. The episode, which took place in a care facility, prompted outrage, questions and a police investigation.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yallambee Lodge, an aged care facility in Cooma, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: Fighting Reported in Russia’s Belgorod Region, Near the Border With Ukraine
item.description: The local Russian governor blamed a Ukrainian sabotage group, while Kyiv’s military intelligence agency said the perpetrators were “opposition-minded citizens of Russia.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Deal Is Reached to Keep Colorado River From Going Dry, for Now
item.description: The agreement on cuts, aided by a wet winter and $1.2 billion in federal payments, expires at the end of 2026.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Matthew Reamer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lake Mead, the largest reservoir in the country, is formed on the Colorado River at the Hoover Dam. The reservoir’s water level has significantly dropped, along with the river.

item.title: Belarus Said to Pardon Roman Protasevich, Activist Who Was Hauled Off a Ryanair Flight
item.description: Roman Protasevich had been sentenced to eight years in prison. The details of his 2021 arrest drew international attention.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The activist Roman Protasevich, center, at a news briefing organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Minsk, Belarus, in 2021.

item.title: Supreme Court Criticism
item.description: Democrats used to criticize the Supreme Court respectfully. Increasingly, they see the court as irredeemable.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court Building in April.

item.title: Zelensky wraps up another fruitful trip and Russia claims a big win in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Soldiers during a night operation near Bakhmut on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s assertions of victory in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing rockets near Bakhmut last week.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The G7 Wraps
item.description: Also, Russia claims that it captured Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky during a speech at the G7.

item.title: As Russia Claims Victory in Bakhmut, Ukraine Sees Opportunity Amid Ruins
item.description: Military analysts say that if Moscow continues to send reinforcements to defend the city, that could weaken Russian forces’ ability to hold off a broader counteroffensive that Ukraine has been planning.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The 80th Air Assault Brigade of Ukraine’s armed forces firing a barrage of rockets in the direction of Bakhmut during a night operation on Tuesday.

item.title: Through Ukraine, Tech Start-Ups Make Their Move Into the U.S. Defense Industry
item.description: Small, fast-moving U.S. tech firms are using the war in Ukraine to demonstrate a new generation of military systems but face the challenge of selling them to a risk-averse Defense Department.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display showing Altius drones, made by Anduril Industries, at a military convention in National Harbor, Md., last month. New advances in autopilot technology helped inspire a flood of American start-ups.

item.title: Zelensky Says Images of a Ruined Hiroshima Remind Him of Bakhmut
item.description: While it “wouldn’t be fair” to compare Hiroshima to what is happening in his country, Ukraine’s president said the city’s atomic bomb museum offered grim echoes of fresh devastation.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Japan’s Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, right, and Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park on Sunday.

item.title: The Evidence for Therapy
item.description: Does talk therapy work? It’s complicated.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez

item.title: Why Does Ukraine Want F-16s?
item.description: Ukraine’s sizable contingent of fighter jets come with a few problems. President Volodymyr Zelensky said F-16s would “greatly enhance our army in the sky.”
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Inside the Barbecue City That Is China’s Hottest Tourist Destination
item.description: Zibo has become a social media star for its distinctive barbecue style. Now the city is overrun with visitors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local BBQ delicacies at a street market in the neighborhood of Badajiao, a street market now turned into a super popular tourist destination in Zibo.

item.title: The U.S. Needs Minerals for Electric Cars. Everyone Else Wants Them Too.
item.description: The United States is entering an array of agreements to secure the critical minerals necessary for the energy transition, but it’s not clear which of the arrangements can succeed.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chaerhan Salt Lake in Golmud, China, where brine is processed to extract lithium and other minerals.

item.title: What Number Comes Next? The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences Knows.
item.description: The “mathematical equivalent to the FBI’s voluminous fingerprint files” turns 50 this year, with 362,765 entries (and counting).
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:description: The Fibonacci sequence, in which every term (starting with the 3rd term) is the sum of the two preceding numbers, is one of the more familiar sequences in the On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, which first appeared as a handbook in 1973.

item.title: As Greece Votes, Leader Says Blocking Migrants Built ‘Good Will’ With Europe
item.description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has taken a tough line on migrants as he turns around the country’s economy. It’s a trade-off that voters and the European Union seem more than willing to abide.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece, leader of the New Democracy party, at a rally in Athens on Friday.

item.title: Rahm Emanuel Pushes Japan on Gay Rights
item.description: The U.S. ambassador has enthusiastically embraced his host country. But critics say he has overstepped diplomatic bounds with his advocacy on equality.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: President Biden being greeted by Rahm Emanuel, the U.S. ambassador to Japan, upon his arrival for the Group of 7 summit on Thursday.

item.title: Russia’s Latest Sanctions on U.S. Officials Turn to Trump Enemies
item.description: Among the 500 people singled out for travel and financial restrictions were Americans seen as adversaries by former President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, on Capitol Hill last year.

item.title: 12 Dead in El Salvador Soccer Stadium Stampede
item.description: It was not immediately clear what prompted the rush at Cuscatlán Stadium in the capital. President Nayib Bukele vowed to conduct a thorough investigation.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: The scene after a deadly stampede at a soccer match on Saturday at Cuscatlán Stadium in San Salvador, El Salvador.

item.title: What’s De-risking and How Does It Compare to Decoupling
item.description: The newly fashionable term, reflecting an evolution in the discussion over dealing with a rising, assertive China, has a vexing history in financial policy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, with President Emmanuel Macron of France with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in April. She was crucial to bringing the term ‘de-risking,’ in the context of China, to wider awareness.

item.title: Typhoon Mawar Heads Toward Guam
item.description: Forecasters said the storm is strengthening as it approaches the Mariana Islands. A typhoon warning is now in effect for Guam and the nearby island of Rota.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Claire Fahy
item.media:description: Typhoon Mawar is expected to strengthen through Tuesday. Forecasts project that it will hit Guam by Wednesday morning.

item.title: Wagner Chief Says Bakhmut Is Taken; Ukraine Rejects Claim
item.description: The head of the Russian paramilitary group said his forces had captured the eastern city, a claim Ukrainian officials were quick to deny even as they called the situation “critical.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian Ground Forces firing shells earlier this month at Russian positions near Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine. The city has become more important symbolically that it is strategically to both sides.

item.title: Battle for Bakhmut: Key Events in Russia-Ukraine War’s Longest Fight
item.description: The city has for months been the center of the fighting in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine. Here’s a look at the critical moments.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A member of Ukraine’s military in Bakhmut in December.

item.title: Bakhmut Exposes Feud Between Russian Officials and Wagner’s Prigozhin
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, once a caterer for the Kremlin, has made capturing the city a personal obsession.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A worker in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Saturday painted over graffiti depicting President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia; Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner paramilitary group; and Ramzan Kadyrov, the head of the Chechen Republic.

item.title: In Flood-Stricken Area of Italy, Residents Fear This Won’t Be the Last of It
item.description: Flooding upended tens of thousands of lives this week in Emilia-Romagna, a region that has also experienced drought in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Elisabetta Zavoli for The New York Times

item.title: The Cannes Film Festival
item.description: Among the films premiering are features from Martin Scorsese, Wes Anderson and Todd Haynes.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Alberta Fires Rage While Election Ignores Global Warming
item.description: For politicians, discussing climate change in a province enriched by oil money is fraught.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jen Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction left behind by wildfires in Drayton Valley, Alberta.

item.title: At G7 Summit, Leaders Wrangle on Coal, Natural Gas and Climate
item.description: The U.S. finds itself caught between defending President Biden’s climate change agenda and aiding allies intent on increasing their access to fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Group of 7 leaders at the Itsukushima Shrine in Japan on Friday. Their final communiqué only modestly modified previous language on natural gas investment.

item.title: Building Boom on Mykonos Reveals ‘Wretched’ Side of Greece’s Recovery
item.description: Investors are eager to cash in on soaring demand for luxury properties, but an attack on an archaeologist investigating building violations brought a darker underbelly to light.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Marco Arguello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction overlooking Panormos Beach and the Principote beach club.

item.title: How Ukraine Changed Russia’s Battle for Bakhmut
item.description: Ukraine, this month, pressed ahead with three days of maneuvers that gained ground on the flanks of Bakhmut. But Russian forces still appear to hold the center of the strategic city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Biden and G7 Summit Partners Struggle for Support Back Home
item.description: The relatively weak approval ratings for President Biden and his Group of 7 partners highlight the fragility of free societies facing deep political divides.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and other Group of 7 leaders on Miyajima island on Friday. Most are struggling for support at home.

item.title: In a Sharp Reversal, Biden Opens a Path for Ukraine to Get Fighter Jets
item.description: The president told allied leaders that he would allow Ukrainian pilots to be trained on American-made F-16s, and is prepared to approve other countries’ transferring the jets to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden and other leaders at the Peace Memorial Park during a visit as part of the G7 Summit in Hiroshima, Japan, on Friday. He surprised his counterparts by telling them he was prepared to allow some European countries to train Ukrainian pilots on F-16 jets.

item.title: Canada Wildfires Rage in Alberta and British Columbia
item.description: Wildfires raging in Alberta and British Columbia have created a sense of panic and fear, and forced thousands of residents to evacuate from their homes.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Jen Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Highway 43, a long stretch of Alberta highway, the thick layer of smoke from wildfires blanketed the road on Thursday.

item.title: Tensions Flare in Georgia as Direct Flights Resume With Russia
item.description: Moscow also eased visa requirements for Georgians. But its actions have stirred fears in Georgia, which was invaded by Russia in 2008.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Tako Robakidze for The New York Times
item.media:description: Azimuth Airlines Flight A4851 was met by about 200 people protesting its arrival.

item.title: U.S. Diplomats in Sudan Shredded Passports, Stranding Sudanese
item.description: Officials destroyed Sudanese passports on security grounds as they evacuated the Khartoum embassy. Now the passport owners are trapped in a war zone.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Sudanese army soldiers guard a checkpoint in Khartoum on Thursday.

item.title: Why the Leaders of Turkey and Thailand Have an Interest in Elections
item.description: Turkey and Thailand held two huge elections this week, both with uncertain outcomes. Each shows some of the benefits that elections can hold for leaders who have amassed power with the tools of the state.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election committee officials counting the envelopes that contained ballots after the presidential and parliamentary elections in Turkey, on Sunday.

item.title: 1923: Germany Seizes French Plane
item.description: Paris claimed a violation of the Treaty of Versailles after the German authorities impounded an aircraft that been forced to land outside Nuremberg because of engine trouble.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Floods in Northern Italy Kill at Least 14
item.description: At least 14 people died and thousands were left homeless after some areas received half their annual rainfall in 36 hours in a region that had only recently finished rebuilding after a 2012 earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani

item.title: Russia says its defense minister visited the Zaporizhzhia area of southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops earlier this year in the Zaporizhzhia region, which is considered a likely focus of Ukraine’s looming counteroffensive.

item.title: Liz Truss, Britain’s Briefest Prime Minister, Meets Taiwan’s Leader
item.description: Liz Truss, the former British prime minister, met Taiwan’s leader, who has sought to push back against China’s efforts to isolate the island democracy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen meeting with former British Prime Minister Liz Truss in Taipei, Taiwan, on Friday.

item.title: Averting a Debt Limit Crisis
item.description: Both parties seem more willing to compromise on the debt limit.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy this week.

item.title: Zelensky Attends Arab League Summit in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Addressing an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged Arab nations to stand with him against Russia and called out their reluctance to take sides in the war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A handout photo shows President Volodymyr Zelensky in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia where he participated in the Arab League summit on Friday.

item.title: How Hillsong, a Hip Megachurch, Became Entangled in Scandal
item.description: A new documentary series explores the history of Hillsong, known for its celebrity congregants and fashionable trappings before being struck by a series of scandals.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A Hillsong service at the Belasco, a venue in Los Angeles, in 2014. The church was known for drawing young people to its services in big cities.

item.title: Rockets Sent Israelis Running From the Beach. A Rare Seal Brought Them Back.
item.description: The incongruous arrival of a large and endangered monk seal has distracted Israelis from a period of violence and political unrest.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: An endangered and rare female Mediterranean monk seal napping in Jaffa, Israel, on Monday.
